sen.j: 紀貫之（き の つらゆき、貞観 (日本)8年または14年（866年、872年）頃? - 天慶9年5月18日 (旧暦)（945年6月19日）?）は、日本の平安時代前期から中期の歌人、随筆家である。
sen.e: KI no Tsurayuki (866 or 872? - June 19, 945?) was a poet and essayist from the early to the middle Heian era.
KI no Tsurayuki (866 or 872? - June 19, 945?) was a poet and essayist from the early to the middle Heian period.
KI no Tsurayuki (866 or 872? - June 19, 945?) was a poet and essayist from the early to the middle Heian period.

sen.j: 三十六歌仙の1人。
sen.e: He was one of the 36 Master Poets.
He was one of the 36 immortal poets.
He was one of the 36 immortal poets.

sen.j: 紀友則は従兄弟にあたる。
sen.e: KI no Tomonori was his cousin.
KI no Tomonori was his cousin.
KI no Tomonori was his cousin.

sen.j: 男性。
sen.e: Male.
Male
Male

sen.j: 幼名は阿古屎（あこくそ）。
sen.e: His childhood name was Akokuso.
His childhood name was Akokuso.
His childhood name was Akokuso.

sen.j: 905年（延喜5年）、醍醐天皇の命により初の勅撰和歌集『古今和歌集』を紀友則、壬生忠岑、凡河内躬恒と共に編纂し、平仮名による序文である仮名序を執筆した。
sen.e: In 905, by order of Daigo Emperor, he compiled "Kokinwakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern)," the first collection of poems by Imperial command, with KI no Tomonori, MIBU no Tadamine, and OSHIKOCHI no Mitsune, and wrote Kanajo (preface written in Hiragana).
sen.cmt: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=壬生忠岑&stype=0&dtype=0http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=凡河内躬恒&stype=1&dtype=0http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=仮名序&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=04218403465800
sen.e: In 905, by order of Emperor Daigo, he compiled "Kokinwakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern)," the first collection of poems by imperial command, with KI no Tomonori, MIBU no Tadamine and OSHIKOCHI no Mitsune, and wrote the kanajo (preface written in Hiragana).

In 905, by order of Emperor Daigo, he compiled "Kokinwakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern)," the first collection of poems by imperial command, with KI no Tomonori, MIBU no Tadamine and OSHIKOCHI no Mitsune, and wrote the kanajo (preface written in Hiragana).

sen.j: 「和歌は、人の心を種として、万の言の葉とぞなれりける」で始まるそれは、後代に大きな影響を与えた。
sen.e: It begins with the following line and exerted a great influence on the posterity; 'Waka has its roots in the human heart and flourishes in myriad leaves of words.'
It began with the following line, which exerted a great influence on posterity: 'Waka has its roots in the human heart and flourishes in the myriad leaves of words.'
It began with the following line, which exerted a great influence on posterity: 'Waka has its roots in the human heart and flourishes in the myriad leaves of words.'

sen.j: また、『小倉百人一首』にも和歌が収録されている（人はいさ心も知らずふるさとは花ぞ昔の香ににほひける）。
sen.e: Also, his waka poem was collected in "Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (One Hundred Poems by One Hundred Poets)" (I'm not sure whether your mind is the same as before. However the Japanese plum, which I know well because I've been here several times, blooms finely and perfumes sweetly to welcome me. Would you come around to put me stay up for the night?).
sen.cmt: http://contest2.thinkquest.jp/tqj2003/60413/index2.html「小倉百人一首」の（）内訳語は「新和英大辞典（研究社）」より（以下、「和大」と表記）
sen.e: Also, his waka poem was collected in "Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (A Hundred Poems by a Hundred Poets)" (I'm not sure whether your mind is the same as before; however the Japanese plum, which I know well because I've been here several times, blooms finely and perfumes sweetly to welcome me; would you come around to help me stay up for the night?).

Also, his waka poem was collected in "Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (A Hundred Poems by a Hundred Poets)" (I'm not sure whether your mind is the same as before; however the Japanese plum, which I know well because I've been here several times, blooms finely and perfumes sweetly to welcome me; would you come around to help me stay up for the night?).

sen.j: 随筆家としては『土佐日記』の著者として有名である。
sen.e: As an essayist, he is well known for his writing "The Tosa Diary."
As an essayist, he is well known for writing "The Tosa Diary."
As an essayist, he is well known for writing "The Tosa Diary."

sen.j: 男は漢文を書くのが常識とされていた時代に、女の作者を装って土佐国から京都までの紀行を平仮名で綴った。
sen.e: In the time when it was common for men to write in Chinese characters, he pretended to be a woman and wrote a journal of his travel from Tosa Province to Kyoto.
In the time when it was common for men to write in Chinese characters, he pretended to be a woman and wrote a journal of his travel from Tosa Province to Kyoto.
In the time when it was common for men to write in Chinese characters, he pretended to be a woman and wrote, in Hiragana, a journal of his journey from Tosa Province to Kyoto.

sen.j: そのため本文中の語り手も女性である。
sen.e: That is why, the narrator of the diary is a woman.
That is why the narrator of the diary is a woman.
That is why the narrator of the diary is a woman.

sen.j: 日本文学史上、おそらく初めての平仮名による優れた散文であり、その後の日記文学や随筆、女流文学の発達に大きな影響を与えた。
sen.e: In the history of Japanese literature, it was probably the first prose written in Hiragana, and had a great influence on the later literature of diary and essay, making a contribution to the development of literature written by female authors.

In the history of Japanese literature, it was probably the first prose written in Hiragana, and it had a great influence on the later literature of diaries and essays, contributing to the development of literature by female authors.

In the history of Japanese literature, it was probably the first prose written in Hiragana, and it had a great influence on the later literature of diaries and essays, contributing to the development of literature by female authors.

sen.j: ※日付＝明治5年12月2日までは旧暦。
sen.e: *Dates = according to the lunar calendar until December 2, 1872.
*Dates = according to the lunar calendar until December 2, 1872
*Dates = according to the lunar calendar until December 2, 1872

sen.j: 866年(貞観_(日本)8)? - 872年(貞観14)?、 このころ生まれる？
sen.e: Between 866? and 872?, he was born?
He was born between 866? and 872. (?)
He was born between 866? and 872. (?)

sen.j: 905年(延喜5)4月、醍醐天皇の勅命により『古今和歌集』を選者の1人として編纂。
sen.e: In April, 905, he compiled "Kokinwakashu" as one of the editors by order of Daigo Emperor.
In April 905, he compiled "Kokinwakashu" as one of the editors by order of Emperor Daigo.
April 905: He compiled "Kokinwakashu" as one of the editors by order of Emperor Daigo.
sen.cmt: 「"On"を使わない日付+半角コロン+半角スペース+文章」の形式に変更しました。

sen.j: 906年(延喜6)2月、越前権少掾に任官。
sen.e: In February, 906, he was appointed Echizen Gonnoshojo.
In February 906, he was appointed Echizen Gonnoshojo.
February 906: He was appointed Echizen Gonnoshojo.

sen.j: 907年(延喜7)2月27日、内膳典膳に遷任。
sen.e: On February 27, 907, he was transferred to Naizen and Tenzen.
On February 27, 907, he was transferred to Naizen and Tenzen.
February 27, 907: He was transferred to Naizen and Tenzen.

sen.j: 9月、宇多天皇が大井川に外出された際に、歌や序を供奉。
sen.e: In September, when Uda Emperor went out to the Oigawa River, he dedicated a poem and a preface to the Emperor.
In September, when Uda Emperor went out to the Oigawa River, he dedicated a poem and a preface to the Emperor.
September: When Emperor Uda went out to the Oigawa River, he dedicated a poem and a preface to the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 同上Emperorの位置移動 他の記事に合わせました。

sen.j: 910年(延喜10)2月、少内記に遷任。
sen.e: In February, 910, he was transferred to Shonaiki.
In February 910, he was transferred to Shonaiki.
February 910: He was appointed Shonaiki.

sen.j: 913年(延喜13)4月、大内記に転任。
sen.e: In April, 913, he was transferred to Dainaiki.
In April 913, he was transferred to Dainaiki.
April 913: He was transferred to Dainaiki.
sen.cmt: 「"On"を使わない日付+半角コロン+半角スペース+文章」の形式に変更しました。

sen.j: 913年(延喜13)、『亭子院歌合』に参加。
sen.e: In 913, he joined "Teiji-in no Uta Awase."
In 913 he joined "Teiji-in no Uta Awase."
913: He joined "Teiji-in no Uta Awase."

sen.j: 屏風画などを作る。
sen.e: He made a folding screen painting and other things.
He made a folding screen painting and other things.
He made a folding screen painting and other things.

sen.j: 917年(延喜17)1月7日、従五位下に叙位。
sen.e: On January 7, 917, he was granted Jugoinoge rank.
On January 7, 917, he was granted the rank of Jugoinoge.
January 7, 917: He was granted the rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade).

sen.j: 大内記如元。
sen.e: He remained a position of Dainaiki.
He remained in the position of Dainaiki.
He remained in the position of Dainaiki.

sen.j: 加賀介兼任。
sen.e: He also held the post of Kaganosuke.
He also held the post of Kaganosuke.
He also held the post of Kaganosuke.

sen.j: 918年(延喜18)2月、美濃介兼任。
sen.e: In February, 918, he was also appointed Minosuke.
In February 918, he was also appointed Minosuke.
February 918: He was also appointed Minosuke.

sen.j: 加賀介任替。
sen.e: He was removed from Kaganosuke.
He was removed from Kaganosuke.
He was removed from Kaganosuke.

sen.j: 923年(延喜23)2月、大監物に遷任。
sen.e: In February, 923, he was transferred to Daikenmotsu (duty).
In February 923, he was transferred to Daikenmotsu (duty).
February 923: He was appointed Daikenmotsu (duty).

sen.j: 929年(延長7)9月、右京亮に転任。
sen.e: In September, 929, he was transferred to Ukyoryo.
In September 929, he was transferred to Ukyoryo.
In September 929, he was transferred to Ukyoryo.

sen.j: 930年(延長8)1月、土佐守に遷任。
sen.e: In January, 930, he was transferred to Governor of Tosa Province.
In January 930, he was transferred to become the governor of Tosa Province.
January 930: He was appointed Governor of Tosa Province.

sen.j: 醍醐天皇の勅命により『新選和歌集』を編纂。
sen.e: He compiled "Shinsen wakashu" by order of Daigo Emperor.
He compiled "Shinsen wakashu" by order of Emperor Daigo.

sen.j: 935年(承平 (日本)5)2月、土佐守の任を終え、帰洛。
sen.e: In February, 935, he finished his duty as Governor of Tosa Province, and went back to Kyoto.
In February 935, he finished his duty as the governor of Tosa Province and returned to Kyoto.

sen.j: 後にこの紀行を参考に、『土佐日記』を書く。
sen.e: Later he wrote "The Tosa Diary" in the light of this journal of the travel.
Later he wrote "The Tosa Diary" as a journal of his travels.
Later he wrote "The Tosa Diary" as a journal of his travels.

sen.j: 940年(天慶3)3月、玄蕃頭に任官。
sen.e: In March, 940, he was appointed Genba no Kami.
In March 940, he was appointed Genba no Kami.

sen.e: On January 7, 943, he was promoted to Jugoinojo rank.
On January 7, 943, he was promoted to the rank of Jugoinojo.

sen.j: 945年(天慶8)3月28日、木工権頭に遷任。
sen.e: On March 28, 945, he was transferred to Moku no Gon no Kami.
On March 28, 945, he was transferred to Moku no Gon no Kami.
March 28, 945: He was appointed Moku no Gon no Kami.

sen.e: In the same year he passed away?

sen.e: On April 18, 1904, he was granted Junii rank.
On April 18, 1904, he was granted the rank of Junii.

sen.j: 霞たちこのめも春の雪ふれば花なきさとも花ぞちりける （古今9）
sen.e: If it starts to haze and snow in spring, it looks like flowers are falling down in a village with no flower. (Kokin 9)
If it starts to haze and snow in spring, it looks like flowers are falling down in a village with no flowers (Kokin 9).
If it starts to haze and snow in spring, it looks like flowers are falling down in a village with no flowers (Kokin 9).

sen.j: 袖ひちてむすびし水のこほれるを春立つけふの風やとくらん （古今2）
sen.e: Will the wind of today, the first day of spring, melt down the frozen water which made my sleeves wet when I scooped? (Kokin 2)
Will the wind of today, the first day of spring, melt down the frozen water that made my sleeves wet when I scooped? (Kokin 2)
Will the wind of today, the first day of spring, melt down the frozen water that made my sleeves wet when I scooped? (Kokin 2)

sen.j: 人はいさ心も知らずふるさとは花ぞ昔の香ににほひける （百人一首35）
sen.e: I'm not sure whether your mind is the same as before. However the Japanese plum, which I know well because I've been here several times, blooms finely and perfumes sweetly to welcome me. Would you come around to put me stay up for the night? (Hyakunin Isshu 35)

I'm not sure whether your mind is the same as before; however, the Japanese plum, which I know well because I've been here several times, blooms finely and perfumes sweetly to welcome me; would you come around to help me stay up for the night? (Hyakunin Isshu 35)

I'm not sure whether your mind is the same as before; however, the Japanese plum, which I know well because I've been here several times, blooms finely and perfumes sweetly to welcome me; would you come around to help me stay up for the night? (Hyakunin Isshu 35)

sen.j: 吉野川いはなみたかく行く水のはやくぞ人を思ひそめてし （古今471）
sen.e: I have fallen in love as fast and rush as the water of Yoshinogawa River goes among rocks with high splash. (Kokin 471)
I have fallen in love as fast and rushing as the water of Yoshinogawa River goes among rocks with great splashing (Kokin 471).
I have fallen in love as fast and rushing as the water of Yoshinogawa River goes among rocks with great splashing (Kokin 471).
